formData.question: What is the difference between var, let, and const in JavaScript?

options.text: var is function scoped, let and const are block scoped
var is block scoped, let and const are function scoped
var and let are function scoped, const is block scoped
var and const are function scoped, let is block scoped

formData.question: What is the difference between == and === in JavaScript?

options.text: == is a loose equality comparison while === is a strict equality comparison
== is a strict equality comparison while === is a loose equality comparison
== is used for string comparison while === is used for numeric comparison
== is used for numeric comparison while === is used for string comparison

formData.question: Which of the following is a closure in JavaScript?

options.text: A function within a function that has access to the outer function's variables
A function that returns another function
A function that does not have any parameters
A function that is immediately invoked

formData.question: What is the difference between null and undefined in JavaScript?

options.text: null represents an intentional absence of any object value while undefined represents an uninitialized variable
null is an object while undefined is a primitive value
null and undefined are the same thing
null is a property of the global object while undefined is a variable in the global scope

formData.question: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous JavaScript?

options.text: Synchronous JavaScript runs in a single thread while asynchronous JavaScript runs in multiple threads
Synchronous JavaScript blocks execution while asynchronous JavaScript does not
Synchronous JavaScript runs faster than asynchronous JavaScript
Synchronous JavaScript runs on the server while asynchronous JavaScript runs on the client

formData.question: What is the purpose of JSX?

options.text: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript, it allows to write HTML elements in JavaScript
JSX is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces
JSX is a pre-processor step that adds XML syntax to JavaScript
JSX is a type of JavaScript that runs on the server
A virtual representation of the actual DOM, it optimizes the process of updating the UI
A lightweight copy of the actual DOM, it allows to make changes in the UI without affecting the real DOM
A JavaScript object that contains the elements of the actual DOM
A tool for debugging the actual DOM

formData.question: What is the difference between state and props in React?

options.text: state is the internal data of a component while props are the data passed from a parent component
state is the data passed from a parent component while props are the internal data of a component
state and props are the same thing
state is used for styling while props are used for data flow

formData.question: What is the difference between a controlled and uncontrolled component in React?

options.text: Controlled components have their state controlled by the parent component, while uncontrolled components manage their own state
Controlled components manage their own state, while uncontrolled components have their state controlled by the parent component
Controlled components are used for forms, while uncontrolled components are used for displaying data
Controlled components are used for displaying data, while uncontrolled components are used for forms

formData.question: What is the purpose of the lifecycle methods in React?

options.text: Lifecycle methods allow a component to control when it is created, updated and destroyed
Lifecycle methods are used for debugging the component
Lifecycle methods are used for styling the component
Lifecycle methods are used for managing the data flow between components
